p: While the science and tools to support these efforts are advancing rapidly, substantial gaps remain between the promise of ES-based approaches and their application in common practice. ES assessments routinely focus on ecosystem properties and processes without considering whether and for whom actual benefits are produced [ 10]. Furthermore, consideration of the impacts of climate change on ES provision is rare, especially outside the U.S. and Europe [ 11]. Methodological differences among ES and climate assessments to date may pose additional challenges to integrated work. These gaps hinder the use of ES information for decision-making that is aimed at delivering durable gains in human well-being through an understanding of synergies and trade-offs between development activities and benefits from nature.
